  • ➤ Educational Objective:

Symptoms of CML include fatigue , night sweats , splenomegaly , petechiae , anaemia , and thrombocytosis . Diagnosis is confirmed by cytogenetic analysis showing the Philadelphia chromosome . Treatment for CML includes targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., imatinib ), which effectively blocks the abnormal protein produced by the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene .

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a long-term indwelling urinary catheter develops fever, dysuria, and pyuria. Urine culture grows a non-lactose fermenting gram-negative rod. Which of the following is the most common non-lactose fermenting organism responsible for catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pseudomonas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common non-lactose fermenting gram-negative bacillus causing catheter-associated UTIs. E. coli is the most common cause of UTI overall but is a lactose fermenter. Shigella spp. is a non-lactose fermenting gram-negative rod, and it is not commonly associated with catheter-associated UTIs. Enterococcus is a gram-positive cause of CAUTI and does not fit the description of a gram-negative non-lactose fermenter. Biofilm formation on catheters contributes to antibiotic resistance and chronic infections.
  • ➤ Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common non-lactose fermenting gram-negative bacillus causing catheter-associated UTIs.
  • ➤ E. coli is the most common cause of UTI overall but is a lactose fermenter.
  • ➤ Shigella spp. is a non-lactose fermenting gram-negative rod, and it is not commonly associated with catheter-associated UTIs.
  • ➤ Enterococcus is a gram-positive cause of CAUTI and does not fit the description of a gram-negative non-lactose fermenter.
  • ➤ Biofilm formation on catheters contributes to antibiotic resistance and chronic infections.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation with a history of gestational hypertension has a tonically contracted uterus, absent fetal heart sounds, hemoglobin of 6 g/dL, and a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, with no visible bleeding on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Concealed abruptio placentae

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient's presentation of abdominal pain, uterine contraction, fetal demise, and the absence of vaginal bleeding is most consistent with concealed abruptio placentae. Abruptio placentae, or placental abruption, refers to the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus. In concealed abruptio placentae, the blood collects behind the placenta, leading to the clinical findings of a contracted uterus, fetal heart absence, and no visible bleeding. It is associated with conditions like gestational hypertension. Key findings: The patient has a history of hypertension, which is a risk factor for placental abruption. The uterus is tonically contracted, there is abdominal pain, and fetal heart tones are absent, all of which suggest placental abruption.
  • • This patient's presentation of abdominal pain, uterine contraction, fetal demise, and the absence of vaginal bleeding is most consistent with concealed abruptio placentae. Abruptio placentae, or placental abruption, refers to the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus. In concealed abruptio placentae, the blood collects behind the placenta, leading to the clinical findings of a contracted uterus, fetal heart absence, and no visible bleeding. It is associated with conditions like gestational hypertension.
  • • Key findings: The patient has a history of hypertension, which is a risk factor for placental abruption. The uterus is tonically contracted, there is abdominal pain, and fetal heart tones are absent, all of which suggest placental abruption.
  • • The patient has a history of hypertension, which is a risk factor for placental abruption. The uterus is tonically contracted, there is abdominal pain, and fetal heart tones are absent, all of which suggest placental abruption.
  • • The patient has a history of hypertension, which is a risk factor for placental abruption. The uterus is tonically contracted, there is abdominal pain, and fetal heart tones are absent, all of which suggest placental abruption.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Revealed placenta previa: Placenta previa usually presents with painless vaginal bleeding, not with abdominal pain, uterine contraction, or absent fetal heart sounds. The absence of visible bleeding and the clinical findings here rule out placenta previa.
  • • Option A. Revealed placenta previa:
  • • Option C. Concealed placenta previa: Concealed placenta previa is not a recognized clinical entity. Placenta previa generally involves bleeding as the placenta partially or completely covers the cervix, but does not cause the uterine contraction seen in this case.
  • • Option C. Concealed placenta previa:
  • • Option D. Revealed abruptio placentae: While abruptio placentae can present with vaginal bleeding, the absence of visible bleeding in this patient suggests the concealed type of abruptio placentae rather than the revealed type.
  • • Option D. Revealed abruptio placentae:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of concealed abruptio placentae, a patient may present with abdominal pain, uterine contraction, and fetal heart sound absence without vaginal bleeding. This condition is associated with a history of gestational hypertension.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department in Hyderabad with sudden-onset breathlessness for the past 30 minutes. He is a known asthmatic on salbutamol and beclomethasone inhalers. On examination, his pulse is 126 bpm, respiratory rate is 28/min, and he is unable to complete full sentences in one breath. CXR shows subcutaneous air. What will be the expected PEF?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • According to the BTS/SIGN guidelines, acute severe asthma is defined by any one of the following features: PEF 33–50% of predicted or best, heart rate ≥110/min, respiratory rate ≥25/min, or inability to complete full sentences in one breath. This patient clearly meets all of these criteria and thus fits into the category of acute severe asthma. The most likely expected PEF is 33%–50%.
  • • .
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 0%–17% – Incorrect. This value is extremely low and is not a standard classification cutoff in the guidelines.
  • • Option A. 0%–17%
  • • Option B. 17%–33% – This implies life-threatening asthma, which is associated with features such as cyanosis, altered consciousness, poor respiratory effort, or silent chest, none of which are present here.
  • • Option B. 17%–33%
  • • Option D. 50%–75% – This range is seen in moderate asthma where severe signs are absent. The presence of tachypnea, tachycardia, and difficulty speaking full sentences indicates a more severe exacerbation.
  • • Option D. 50%–75% –

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In asthma assessment, clinical severity should align with defined guideline thresholds. According to BTS/SIGN guidelines, a patient with heart rate ≥110, respiratory rate ≥25, and inability to complete full sentences is categorized as having acute severe asthma. The expected PEF in such cases is 33%–50%. Life-threatening asthma requires more critical features such as PEF <30%, cyanosis, or altered mental status.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with progressive fatigue, weight loss, and skin hyperpigmentation. Laboratory investigations reveal hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and elevated ACTH levels. Which of the following best explains the reason for this patient’s hyperpigmentation?

options.label: B
options.text: ACTH is derived from POMC, which also produces melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH).

options.label: C
options.text: ACTH upregulates melanin synthesis by increasing tyrosinase activity in melanocytes.

options.label: D
options.text: ACTH stimulates beta-endorphin production, leading to darkened skin.

questions.correct_answer: B. ACTH is derived from POMC, which also produces melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH).
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) ACTH is derived from POMC, which also produces melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Hyperpigmentation in ACTH overproduction occurs due to increased MSH levels, a byproduct of POMC-derived ACTH synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms can be effectively isolated using NNN (Novy-MacNeal-Nicolle) medium? Leishmania donovani Giardia E. histolytica Trichomonas vaginalis Trypanosoma cruzi

Trypanosoma cruzi (Chagas disease) grows as epimastigotes in NNN culture. Giardia lamblia, Entamoeba histolytica, and Trichomonas vaginalis require different culture media and do not grow on NNN medium.

questions.text: The graph compares the arterial anesthetic tension over time for nitrous oxide and a new anesthetic agent (Drug A). Compared to nitrous oxide, Drug A exhibits a slower rise in arterial tension. Which of the following best describes the properties of Drug A?

questions.text: Mr. Rohan, a 33-year-old man from Delhi, presents with recurrent episodes of sudden breathlessness and wheezing, particularly worsening in cold weather. He has a history of atopic dermatitis, managed with topical hydrocortisone. He denies fever, weight loss, or night sweats. Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ FeNO >40 ppb supports airway inflammation, but spirometry confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding endolymph and perilymph in the inner ear are correct? Endolymph is found within the membranous labyrinth , while perilymph is located between the membranous labyrinth and the bony labyrinth . Endolymph is rich in potassium ions, resembling intracellular fluid, whereas perilymph is rich in sodium and chloride ions, resembling extracellular fluid. Endolymph transmits sound waves to hair cells , while perilymph transmits sound waves to the endolymph . Perilymph has a more positive electric potential compared to endolymph . Endolymph and perilymph are functionally important for both hearing and balance.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3 and 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endolymph is rich in potassium, found in the membranous labyrinth, and has a more positive electric potential, whereas perilymph is sodium-rich, found between the membranous and bony labyrinths, and transmits sound waves to the endolymph. Both are essential for hearing and balance.
  • ➤ Endolymph is rich in potassium, found in the membranous labyrinth, and has a more positive electric potential, whereas perilymph is sodium-rich, found between the membranous and bony labyrinths, and transmits sound waves to the endolymph.
  • ➤ Both are essential for hearing and balance.

  • ➤ Lathyrism results from chronic consumption of the Lathyrus sativus legume, containing the neurotoxin BOAA, which specifically affects motor neurons and leads to spastic paralysis, especially of the lower limbs, without affecting sensory or cognitive functions. Awareness of dietary habits is crucial in diagnosing neurolathyrism in regions where Lathyrus is commonly consumed.

questions.text: A 10-day-old neonate presents with bilateral mucopurulent eye discharge and mild eyelid swelling. Gram stain is negative, but Giemsa stain reveals intracellular inclusions. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oral erythromycin

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 2-month-old male presents with severe failure to thrive, chronic diarrhea, and recurrent infections (Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, persistent oral thrush). Laboratory tests show: Lymphocyte count: 200 cells/µL Serum IgG, IgA, IgM: Absent Flow cytometry: Absent T and B cells Which of the following is the most likely genetic defect in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Deficiency of complement C1 esterase inhibitor

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with schizophrenia has been taking chlorpromazine for the past six months. Which of the following side effects is least likely to be caused by chlorpromazine?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chlorpromazine can cause extrapyramidal symptoms (drug-induced Parkinsonism), hyperprolactinemia (amenorrhea), and dermatologic side effects (skin rash, photosensitivity). It is not associated with osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old HIV-positive male presents with persistent cough and weight loss. His sputum smear microscopy is negative, but tuberculosis is still suspected. Under NTEP guidelines, which of the following tests should be performed next for rapid confirmation of TB?
questions.correct_answer: C. Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT)
questions.explanation:
